question: What are two responsibilities that you will have as a British citizen or permanent resident of the UK?
choice1: To look after the area in which you live and the environment
choice2: To look after yourself and your family
choice3: To stay in the UK forever
choice4: To promote work in your local community
explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should:look after yourself and your family, look after the area in which you live and the environment, respect and obey the law, respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions and treat others with fairness.

question: Where is Big Ben located?
explanation: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clockat the Houses of Parliament in London.

question: When were men and women given the right to vote at the age of 21?
explanation: In1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

explanation: The UK is located in thenorth west of Europe.

question: Who is the patron Saint of Scotland?

question: Which two houses fought in the Wars of the Roses?
explanation: The Wars of the Roses were fought between the supporters of two families:the House of Lancaster and the House of York.

question: The Bill of Rights of 1689 confirmed the right to vote for all adult men.
explanation: False. The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power.

question: What is the Cenotaph?
explanation: The Cenotaph isa war memorialand it is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the King, politicians and foreign ambassadors.

explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired bythe Speaker.

question: What is the minimum age required to serve on a jury?
explanation: Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged18to 70 can be asked to serve on a jury.

question: How is a jury selected?
explanation: As well as getting the right to vote,people on the electoral register are randomly selectedto serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

question: What is a bank holiday?
choice1: A public holiday when banks are open all day
choice2: A public holiday for people working in banks
choice3: An additional day off that every worker in the UK is entitled to
choice4: A public holiday when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day
explanation: There are public holidays each year called bank holidays,when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day.

explanation: The Channel Islandsis a British overseas territory linked to the UK, but it is not part of it.
